comments.value:
Hi Lakshmi

Do you have any referrer's for these requests? as it will be easier to track down any 404's if we know where they we're referenced from.

It may be the case that these requests come from cached versions of pages that we no longer host, so would be good to eliminate those first as they obviously can never be fixed.

In terms of the top three:

1) bt-logo-transparent.png
This is really confusing us, we just checked a few pages ie. webcams and the logo appears fine / no 404 are appearing. We are wondering if these errors could be down to a script / spider polling for those images directly and the url not having been changed? This is where the referrer's would come in handy.

2) www.london2012.com/ntytwelve/two_years_to_go/two_years_to_go_home.swf"
This looks like a broken reference to a Flash movie on this page http://www.london2012.com/splash/index.php But I can't see any issue or reference to that path, this was a page on which the HTMl was edited manually by LOCOG (ie. not edited in the CMS or constructed by us) and it may have been that an earlier version had the broken link.

3) js/login.js 
We'll see if we can track down js/login.js as that file no longer exists, but it may be getting reference somewhere in a header.

4) /images/icons/venues/%C3%A9quitation%20-%20concours%20complet.gif
These paths are for icons, we think this is down to Translations.com translating meta data tags on the French site which although in the feed we send then they are not meant to translate (we flag them as non-translatable so they should get ignored). The knock on effect here is that because we use the Meta tag name to retrieve the icon for the page it is not being found. We thought we had cleaned these up and informed the translation company but will double check to see if it is still happening anywhere.

If the refereeing page/section is possible guessable ie. requests for .js or images within the /photo or /webcams section you could go at look at a selection of those pages (you only need to look at one page of each type) to see if you can spot any broken referrers just using a tool like Firebug on Firefox (too see what assets are/aren't loading). Although having just done this on both the webcam and image hubs and the pages themselves I can't see any issues / broken paths. Although that's not to say there aren't issues on other pages/

With regards to resolving the rest of them I think we really need to see the REFERER pages or else we are looking for a needle in a haystack, to make matters worse some of these requests may be from old cached copied of pages, requests from robots scraping the page (but not doing so properly and hence garbling urls).

If we know on which page these requests are coming from we can then check those pages and if a path is broken quickly fix it. 

Although we may find that many of these 404 are direct requests by a robot or script (which has ignored the 'base href' tag and so is looking for paths relatively to a page and not the root of the site) or from cached copies of old pages.

Jamie

On 17 Aug 2010, at 10:08, Nagalakshmi Musunuri wrote:

Hi Danny/Jamie,

BT has been noticing 404 errors on www.london2012.com and they have become increasingly concerned since they are currently planning to migrate all applications to new BT infrastructure under managed services. I have attached the latest set of 404 errors from 1st August to till date for your reference.

Though I agree with Jamie that these errors are mostly caused by css changes, we still need to find the actual source of these errors and need to resolve them asap. Hence, could you please let me know when would it be convenient to discuss this on a call?

As you are aware, we do have few resources and can definitely look to work with you to resolve these issues.

Please advice if you have any thoughts on how to resolve these 404 errors.

Thanks,
Lakshmi Musunuri
LOCOG Technology
Direct line: +44 (0) 30 2012 0233 (Please note my new number)

Some of the above errors can be fixed, the rest I think we need to wait for referers although we should take a look over the Excel file to see if we can spot any other glaring oddities.

1) French tags being translated resulting in broken links to icons (separate tickets need to be opened (and charged for, which could be time consuming/expensive to resolve)
2) Finding references to js/login.js

The BT logo one is odd, I wonder if BT is spidering their logo for some odd reason? or maybe it's just some old cached CSS.

1 day emails (jamie)
1 IE8 issues (jamie+kieran)
0.5 fixing (jamie)
0.3 fixing (kieran)
0.2 fixing (kieran)
0.1 meeting (kieran)
Items:
- links on splash page (non-CMS)
- links on ORN site (non-CMS)
- renamed icons
- IE8 bug with base href issues

Hi Liz,

OK fixed this :)

1) The old volunteering pages didn't have the 'hide-from-nav' box checked.

2) But (and this is the bit worth remembering as I have just been going crazy figuring out whey my changes didn't get picked up!!)

The drop down navigation include [ http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/includes/nav-dropdown.php ] get cached by the CMS (so you don't have to wait for it to render each time).

But if anything changes, you need to open the include in edit mode and re save to clear the cache.
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/includes/nav-dropdown.php

Log/short of it, is that it's working now..

Have a good weekend if I don't speak to you before..

Jamie

Hi Alex.
I'm looking into fixing this instance of the problem.
To fix this properly, moving forward, I will need to make some changes to our core CMS code.
I estimate this taking about 3/4 day, so I'll need approval before embarking on this.

The image from SiteEyeLive is truncated:
  http://www.siteeyelive.com/monitor/london2012/camputer128.jpg
as such, there is little I can do to fix it. The last few images that we've retrieved have been like this.
Once I've put in place the fix detailed above, we will just be able to leave it showing the "last good image".

ok, current picture looks ok
 http://www.siteeyelive.com/monitor/london2012/camputer128.jpg 
so I'm rerunning the feed.

Thanks, Liz can you authorise this fix needed?


Alex

Yes – definitely go ahead and do it.

Kieran – what appears to be the issue? Is it a bug in something that hasn’t been implemented as expected, or is it a change in the webcam that’s resulted in the issue?

Basically, occasionally siteeyelive leave truncated jpegs on the webserver. For example,
  http://www.siteeyelive.com/monitor/london2012/camputer128.jpg
currently displays the attached file.
Currently we don't have the ability - in the cms - to check whether it is truncated/incomplete or not. As you can (maybe) imagine. it's a little tricky.
Once we can check for such images, we can simply ignore them, and hope that the next time we check, the image isn't truncated.
It might be something that siteeyelive can/should fix, but - regardless of that - we should perform  this check, to be 100% safe.

This change is now live.
I'm watching it to double-check that it catches truncated images.
I would be grateful if you could immediately forward me any evidence of truncated webcam images or of out-of-date images appearing.
Thanks,
Kieran

Ok, there have not been any truncated images in the last 24 hours, but I'll set this ticket to closed - I'll carry on checking the logs though, to check that truncated images are being ignored correctly.

Ticket #1085 "add method for checking for trun..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #1085: nice solution.

Hi Uzma,
Can I just double-check what led you to believe that the scheduling had not worked?
I ask, because the log files are telling me that videos/2010/lee-valley-white-water-centre.php was indeed published by the scheduler at 10:00:55. Once it is "published" (which should more accurately be known as "queued for publication", it then takes a minute or so for the cms to actually promote it to the live servers. There is then a synchronisation process (which Kitsite has no control over) which can then take up to 5 minutes to push the updates across all of the live servers. The upshot is that - even if scheduling was working perfectly - your page would not have appeared on the live site for up to 5 or 6 minutes (sometimes even longer, at busy times).
The next time you schedule a page for publication could you let us know before you do it please, so that someone can (virtually!) look over your shoulder to see what is going wrong.
Thanks in advance,
Kieran
This ticket was closed and merged into ticket #1165 "Re: Scheduling in the CMS".

Looks to me as if the max font size (35px) far exceeds the line-height of the tag cloud "li" (1.636em).

Three solutions suggest themselves:
1. We could allow the line height to vary; perhaps that would look ugly though?
2. We could restrict the tag cloud to Y px, where Y is less than the current 35.
3. The tag cloud could output size in "em" rather than "px", thus ensuring that it never exceeds1.636em
3 seems the most sensible? Lars? Janos?

Ok, this is fixed on dev:
  http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/preview/photos/index.php
I'm reluctant to deploy this fix before I leave on Friday, so I'll put it off until Mon.
In particular, the following needs to be deployed:
  module-tagcloud
  Navigation.getTagCloud()
Tested in IE8, FF3, Safari.

Note it wasn't quite as simple as (3.) as 1.636em related to the line-height, rather than font-size.
I had to play around with various values. The range of 1em -> 2.5em seems to work best (but can be amended if need be).

Ok, this is now fixed and deployed:
  http://www.london2012.com/photos/
The range of font-sizes can be trivially amended- if need be.

Time breakdown as follows:
 0.1 = diagnosis
 0.1 = fixing/tweaking/testing
 0.1 = deployment to live + further tweaks.
Technical note: font size / units can be amended in Navigation,getTagCloud() {}.

Fixed. When a webcam image gets corrupted it does eventually get re-written as the feed is running hourly, I believe. 

In order to prevent these grey images being published we would probably need to put some sort of check in each time an image is collected.

Please can we look into? The same has just happened to another one!


Alex

Hi Alex,

We've got another ticket open which is looking at a workaround to resolve what we hope is the root cause of this.
http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/1085

Although fine to leave this ticket open though, as the above one is more techieand the title of it will probably only make sense to us :-)

Basically the problem happens because as we are retrieving an image from SiteEyes server and maybe half way though retrieving it, SiteEye come along and slap a new version over the one of the one we are in the process of retrieving, which means the image we get back is sometimes corrupt. 

It's 'kind of' an issue at SiteEye's end, but as I can't think of an easy fix they can make and all JPG's should end in \xFF\xD9 (and the corrupt images we have seen seem to have been truncated) we're going to see if checking for this value roots out any broken / corrupt images, in which case we'll try and retrieve the image.

Will let you know how we get on..

Jamie

* it's not going to be a quick fix, ie. we're unlikely to get it fixed today as we need to do some work in the CMS to handle the checking, but we are actively working on it...

** you could mention to SiteEye that we are hitting an issue where we think the images (on their server) are being overwritten/updated while we are in the process of trying to retrieve them, but can't think of an easy fix SiteEye can make to get round this at their end.
Ok, thanks Jamie.

This is who Morag bought the cert form last year,

Simon Knight <S.Knight@quovadisglobal.com>
http://www.quovadisglobal.com/

ITS/BT/We need to send then the CSR (below)

They will then send back a .crt file which needs installing on web01-06

We didn't install the cert on the servers initially, although did install it last time and although this is really is a systems task, I'm happy to install the certs again if that would be quicker/easier.

The main thing I remember is that if there's an issue with the cert the webserver may refuse to start up. As I understand it if a web server is down the Load Balancer won't send traffic to a dead server (so we should be fine), although I am not 100% confident of this (may be worth checking with BT). As the cert is tied to a domain name / the csr and the staging server is not currently setup as an exact clone of the live servers we can't properly test it on the staging environment first. This is just me being extra cautious rather than I problem I necessarily foresee. 

Although saying all the above it looks as if the Certificate that a public user see's isn't the one installed on the server but rather an Akamai certificate? Although this a slightly outside of my field of knowledge, it's probably worth checking with Akamai.

Jamie

Hi Liz,

The problem is the pages get created by the feed and the name of the page is fixed in the feed (as it's used to create the page initially)

If a webcam is renamed or deleted, the feed just sees that the page is missing an tries to recreate it.

1) We're fixing it (buy updating the feed to match the new webcam page name)
2) In future it may be worth reminding everyone that you can't rename or delete a webcam in the CMS, it needs to happen in the feed (well you can do it in the CMS but the feed will just recreate the page!)

Will send a update once we have fixed the current mis-match

Ok, the webcams index page is now fixed.
 http://www.london2012.com/webcams/index.php
As per jamie's comment, the problem is that renaming a webcam is NOT simply a matter of renaming the Photo pages in the Webcams folder.
With each rename, a relatively trivial change needs to be made to the Webcam feed (the code which collects the images and places them on the website).
I'll write a very brief help topic on the subject but - essentially - if a webcam needs to be renamed, please create a new ticket.
http://postcms.zendesk.com/entries/235488-renaming-webcams

comments.value:
Jag/Jamie,
 
Just looked at the Akamai portal – we are still getting some 404 errors and I’d like to get these items scrubbed out of the javascripts and the css if at all possible.
 

 
In terms of load it’s not an issue now but in the games time it may become an issue – if we know these objects don’t exist (which was the reason given last week) then these are requests that don’t need to come back to the origin and hence is load the origin services don’t need to carry.
 
Whilst we are so lightly loaded we need to bed in the processes to ensure that the sites run in their most efficient way.
 
Hope you agree.
 
Also there has been an icrease in the rate of 304 responses indicating that the expiry threshold for some of the objects is probably set too low. Again – let’s practice with this during this quiet period in order to ensure that come games time we have a managed situation such that the origin servers don’t fall over.
 
I have a hospital appointment on Tuesday and won’t be there but we can have a discussion on the phone.
 
Col.
Colin Bell
BT Global Services

From: Jamie Unwin [mailto:jamie@kitsite.com] 
Sent: 02 August 2010 18:35
To: Jagdeep Bhambra
Subject: Re: 404 errors and security

Hi Jag,

We've been looking though the logs (see attached) to see if we can spot the most problematic 404's the issue doesn't seem to be down to a simple set of 'rouge' images.

The CSS file seems to be a red herring, hopefully we cleaned up all of these earlier in the year. 

Almost all images / pages assigned editorially in the CMS are dependency tracked, the exception here is external links (as their may be a requirement to link to a site which is not yet live or is temporarily down).

The following seem to be the main issues we could see it the log today, in order of issue (ie. the top issue is by far the biggest source of 404's).

Will let you know how we progress, esp. with the first issue (as that is by far the biggest problem we are seeing).

Jamie

1) Quite a few of direct (ie. no referrer page) references to section paths like this /get-involved/images or get-involved/volunteer/css or /games/venues/js; we're investigation if this is due to some browsers having issues with the JS or CSS (if it is it may need to go back to CogApp). Still investigating. One suspect here is some JS (for example a image carousel) that loops though images inside a given <div> tag, by appending a filename to a set path ie. "/image/location" + "image1.jpg" if there is no image then the code will try to retrieve the folder alone. Obviously where we have written any JS code that has this issue we can fix it. But a lot of the JS on the site was supplied by CogApp / McCann as self contained libraries. Obviously we are trying to gather as much info here as possible as this seems the biggest source of 404's

Status: open, moved to new/seperate ticket

2) /ntytwelve (fixed) this was a broken path to an externally hosted video pasted in buy the editorial team; it was missing the [ http://89.234.19.19/twe ] bit and so was looking for the file locally. Internal links to other page sin the CMS *are* dependency tracked, it's just any path that sites outside the CMS and needs an absolute url to it.

Status: fixed

3) This is a microsite which sites outside of our control; will look at fixing / getting the relevant people at ODA to fix.
/apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/olympic-route-network/css/print.css, referer: http://www.london2012.com/olympic-route-network/home.html
[Mon Aug 02 07:44:33 2010] [error] [client 80.239.234.182] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/olympic-route-network/css/print.css

Status: ODA checking to see if a print.css was supplied, if not all references to it in the HTMl will need to be updated (note: this is a microsite that is not handled as part of the CMS)

4) Links to old paths on the current site, I guess we could add a permanent redirect is applicable, will try and identify the worst offenders / ask editorial where to redirect traffic. 
[Mon Aug 02 06:50:37 2010] [error] [client 80.239.205.21] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/webcams/images/original/stadium-long.jpg, referer: http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=979032
[Mon Aug 02 07:23:48 2010] [error] [client 124.40.50.178] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/photos/venues, referer: http://www.google.co.id/imglanding?q=stadion%20indonesia%202022&imgurl=http://u.kaskus.us/2/gfgyx0hr.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.kaskus.us/showthread.php%3Fp%3D243269338&usg=__vEFptVoCnVADEJqLLZO3jCThoVI=&h=377&w=502&sz=30&hl=id&itbs=1&tbnid=chJsxrGkj_ohiM:&tbnh=98&tbnw=130&prev=/images%3Fq%3Dstadion%2Bindonesia%2B2022%26hl%3Did%26sa%3DG%26tbs%3Disch:1&sa=G&tbs=isch:1&start=2

Status: LOCOG to create a list of old / new urls where applicable. Error logs or Google Analytics will first need scanning to identify request for old pages (as opposed to broken paths or other requests).

5) These look like a bug with translation.com translating paths in the XML we send them (they're aren't meant to touch these fields !) / will fix.
[Mon Aug 02 07:17:51 2010] [error] [client 80.239.234.182] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/images/icons/venues/discipline aquatique - water-polo.gif, referer: http://www.london2012.com/fr/games/venues/index.php

Status: have updated instances of bug, but need to make sure translation company doesn't send these in future. We are in the process of switching translation company so will highlight with new company.

6) This one looks like volleyball got renamed to Beach volleyball and so the image (based on the sprt name) couldn't be found, have fixed.
[Mon Aug 02 07:41:32 2010] [error] [client 195.12.231.136] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/new.london2012.com/images/icons/venues/volleyball-beach.gif, referer: http://www.london2012.com/games/venues/index.php

Status: resolved

Jamie responded "We've just a done a scan of a section of the site attached and the tags are all coming up as valid."

We checked the published pages for possible errors, logged into Google analytics to check the pattern of data loss and used some third party tools for checking the validity of the tags. As Jamie says, we could not find a problem and we also identified a strange pattern of data loss (No problems on Tuesday, no data at all for all of Wednesday, back to normal from midnight last night and no data again from 6am today), which seems to imply that it is likely to be a temporary problem with Google and we hope more to do with reporting than data collection. In other words, this looks to be out of our hands and the gaps in the data may be filled in later in the week, rather than lost for good.

I think we have had this temporary data loss with Google before. Liz, as our resident analytics queen, what are your thoughts?
________________________________________

I'm hopeful (though not necessarily optimistic) that the data will simply reappear in another day or two. It has happened before where Google are just running tests or something odd and the site looks like it's lost traffic for 24-48 hours...

-----Original Message-----
The missing data for Wednesday has appeared. It does look like this is a temporary issue with the reporting of GA data that is sorting itself out now. Marking as solved.
